header.title: A Witch's Guide to Ghosts and the Supernatural

central_thesis: This guide posits the tangible reality of ghosts and supernatural phenomena, offering a syncretic framework for understanding, interacting with, and protecting oneself from these entities. It integrates personal anecdotes, historical context, and practical magical and spiritual techniques from diverse traditions, emphasizing a Witch's perspective on operative spirit work.

structure_content.summary: The author shares compelling personal experiences with ghosts and the supernatural, including a childhood séance, haunted hotels, and an encounter at the House of Seven Gables, setting an experiential tone for the book. It also dedicates the book to those who nurtured her interest in the occult.

This section asserts the universal and historical presence of ghosts, distinguishing between 'energy imprints' (ghosts unaware of the living) and 'conscious spirits' (aware and interactive). It contrasts Christian views of ghosts as demons with more nuanced occult perspectives, and discusses the role of fear and misunderstanding in human perceptions of spirits.

Explores the nature of ghosts, poltergeists (violent, non-apparition phenomena), cold spots, and spirit portals. It provides an overview of how spirits might manifest in dreams, offering various dream interpretations from Gustavus Hindman Miller and Nerys Dee. The chapter also covers animal spirits and the distinction between benign and evil spirits, providing initial protective measures.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 2: True Tales of Ghosts and Hauntings
structure_content.summary: A compilation of first-hand accounts of paranormal experiences by the author and other practitioners. Stories detail poltergeist activity, apparitions, spirit interactions in haunted houses (Sunnybrae, Moses Day Homestead, Dunwich Manor), and a slumber party séance, illustrating various manifestations and personal impacts of the supernatural.

Traces the historical development of spiritualism, its peak popularity, and its modern practice. It provides detailed instructions and precautionary measures for communicating with spirits using Ouija boards and conducting séances, including the role of mediums and specific ritual steps for contact and closure. An interview with spiritual medium Tim Braun offers contemporary insights.

Defines necromancy as divination by conjuring the dead, contextualizing its historical practice across cultures and distinguishing it from 'black magic'. It details ancient rituals, the risks involved, and includes an interview with a modern necromancer who discusses the path, its dangers, and the difference between 'black' (malicious intent) and 'white' (divination/enlightenment) forms.

Categorizes possession into spirit (voluntary, culturally sanctioned) and demonic (harmful takeover). It explores possession in Voodoo and Neo-Paganism, and outlines the three stages of possession (Partial Influence, Partial Possession, Total Possession) from a Christian perspective. The chapter also details the Roman Catholic rite of exorcism as described in the Rituale Romanum, including its historical context and symptoms.

A practical guide to operative magic for spirit interaction. It provides specific incantations for spirit evocation and banishing, spells for summoning spirits, and methods for home protection against evil entities, including herbal remedies, mojo bags, and instructions for enchanting necromancer's candles and preparing spirit-related incenses.

Lists and describes various 'ghost flowers' (Mohavea confertiflora, Monotropa uniflora, Datura) and other plants with occult significance related to spirits. It offers instructions for creating a 'spirit garden' to attract specific entities and a comprehensive list of herbs used in different magical traditions for both conjuring and banishing spirits, alongside Saint John's Wort for protection.

Explores a diverse collection of historical and folkloric superstitions surrounding ghosts, death, and protective practices from various cultures. Topics include burial customs, omens of death, ghost sightings, and beliefs about individuals born under specific astrological or calendrical conditions ('chime children').

Examines the folklore, characteristics, and methods of protection against vampires and werewolves. It delves into Slavic vampire legends, Gypsy vampire lore (mullos, dhampirs), methods to become and destroy vampires, and the origins of werewolf legends. It also includes details on shapeshifting magic and ways to ward off werewolves using specific plants and amulets.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 10: Deities of Death and the Underworld
structure_content.summary: A catalog of various gods and goddesses associated with death and the underworld from different global mythologies, including Mayan (Ah Puch, Chamer, Cizin, Cum Hau, Ikal Ahau, Ixtab, Mictlantecutli, Tokakami, Tia, Yum Cimil), Egyptian (Aker, Ament, Andjety, Anubis, Heret-Kau, Isdes, Khentimentiu, Nephthys, Nehebkau, Seker, Serket, Wepwawet), Greek (Atropos, Hades, Thanatos), Roman (Mors, Morta, Naenia, Orcus, Proserpina, Tellus), Celtic (Balor, Morrigan), Etruscan (Charun, Lasa, Mania, Tuchulcha, Vanth), African (Itonde, Na Ngutu, Ndjambi, Ogiuwu), Babylonian (Nergal, Ninedinna), Chinese (Chu Jiang, Yan-lo), Hindu (Kala, Rudra, Yama), Inca (Supay, Vichana), Norse (Hel, Ran, Odin), Polynesian (Fe'e, Hine-Nui-Te-Po, Merau, Savea Si’uleo).
A directory of organizations, societies, ghost tours, and individual practitioners related to paranormal research, spiritualism, and ghost hunting, including contact information and websites.
An alphabetical listing of key terms used throughout the book, providing definitions for concepts related to spirits, psychic abilities, magical practices, and paranormal phenomena.
A list of books and other sources cited or referenced by the author, indicating the scholarly foundation and influences for the text's content.

A biography of Gerina Dunwich, highlighting her background as a practicing Witch, ordained minister, astrologer, Tarot reader, and author of numerous occult books. It mentions her personal interests and experiences with haunted locations.

key_concepts.definition: A materialized ghost or spirit. The appearance of a person’s phantom, living or dead, seen in a dream or in the waking state as the result of astral projection or clairvoyance.

A solid object, either animate or inanimate, that manifests during a séance or a haunting by non-physical means. Apports are sometimes made of teeth, hair, feces, or vomit of either an animal or human.
The plane of existence and perception that parallels the dimension of the physical and is the plane that the astral body reaches during astral projection and death.

Also known as astral travel or out of body experience, this is when the spirit travels outside of the body either to the astral plane or another location on the physical, or earthly, plane; the separation of the consciousness from the physical body resulting in an altered state of consciousness. Astral projections can be achieved by a number of trance-inducing methods or imagination techniques.

An emanation of energy that surrounds all living things. Many persons possessing psychic abilities are able to see and interpret this energy. Can be viewed as colored lights through the use of Kirlian photography. Many aura readers believe that a person’s physical health is reflected in his or her aura.

A method of spirit communication by which a medium enters a trance state and allows a spirit to control his or her hands to write messages. Many parapsychologists believe that this type of phenomena is due to automatism (suspension of the conscious mind in order to release subconscious images).
To release or drive away a conjured spirit.
A spirit that is not evil or harmful to man. Elementals and spirit guides fall into this category, as do spirits of loved ones that return from the dead to bring us a message or warning.

The uncommon phenomenon of a person or object appearing in two distant places simultaneously. A number of Christian saints and monks were famous for bilocation. It is said that spontaneous and involuntary bilocation sometimes occurs shortly before, or at the moment of, the death of a person whose double is seen.

A person with mediumistic abilities who engages in the channeling of spirits, or in other words, allows a person to use his or her vocal chords as an instrument through which it can communicate with the living.
The psychic ability to hear spirit voices or sounds attributed to the dead; an auditory form of extrasensory perception.
The psychic ability to feel things not normally felt by most people.
The extrasensory ability to perceive persons, objects, or events that are out of the range of average human senses.
The act of evoking spirits by means of formulas or words of power.

A low-level and inhuman spirit that interacts in the affairs of the mortal world. It is said there exist numerous varieties of demons. Some are good; some are evil; and some are a combination of both. (The word “demon” means “replete with wisdom” and derives from the Greek, daimon, which means “divine power” or “a god.”)
The human double, astral body, or ghost resembling a person who is still alive. The word is German in its origin and means “double walker.” Known in Sweden as a vardoger.
A mysterious substance that emanates from the body or mouth of a spiritualist medium in trance during a séance. Ectoplasm often appears as a white, mist-like substance.
An instrument that measures electromagnetic energy and is frequently used by field researchers of ghosts and hauntings. Also known as a Gauss Meter or magnetometer.
Voices captured on magnetic audiotape when no one is present are believed to be voices from spirits attempting to communicate with the living.
A ritual designed to expel an evil spirit or demon from a possessed person or place. Also known as deliverance.

The spirit or apparition of a dead person that appears to the living or returns to haunt a former habitat; the disembodied spirit of a person who has died. Animals and inanimate objects such as ships and buildings can also be ghosts. Other words for ghost include phantom, shade, specter, and wraith.

A book of spells, rituals, formulas, and incantations designed to evoke spirits, demons, and angels. The Key of Solomon, written in medieval times and still in print today, is perhaps the single most famous grimoire used by sorcerers and ceremonial magicians. Grimoire is a French word that means “conjuring-book.”

The unexplainable appearance of an image of a person, animal, or inanimate object on a frequent or regular basis in a particular location. A state of existence under which a human or inhuman spirit has attached itself to a person, place, or inanimate object.
The spirit of a person who once lived on the physical plane of existence. Human spirits can remain earthbound for various reasons. Compare with Inhuman Spirit.
A demon, specifically male in characteristics, said to cause nightmares as well as engage in sexual intercourse with mortal women while they sleep.

The spirit of a creature that has never lived on the physical plane of existence. Inhuman spirits that are benevolent by nature are often classified as angels, while malevolent ones are classified as demons and devils. Also known as a non-human spirit. Compare with Human Spirit.
The raising and floating of an object or person by means of supernatural forces, magick, or psychokinetic powers.
A type of spirit disposed to evil. A malicious or spiteful spirit. Such an entity often destroys things of financial or sentimental value for the mere sake of hurting someone.
The appearance of, or taking form of, an entity. This word is also used to denote an outbreak of spirit or poltergeist activity.

A gifted person who receives messages, impressions, and other communications from the spirit world. Mental mediums communicate with spirits without necessarily entering a trance state. Physical mediums generally operate from a trance state and may produce materializations, apports, or rappings.
The art and practice of divining the future by raising corpses or by conjuring the spirits of the dead.
From the Latin occulere, meaning, “to hide,” a term referring to the body of knowledge that is hidden or secret in the areas of the supernatural, paranormal, or preternatural.
A sphere of electromagnetic energy produced by spirits. Also known as a globule.

A special game board manufactured by the Parker Brothers company and marked with letters of the alphabet, numbers, and the words “yes” and “no.” It is used in conjunction with a pointed indicator called a “planchette” as a device for divination and as a means to communicate with the spirits of the dead.

From the German polter, “uproar,” and geist, “ghost,” a word given to the type of phenomenon in which sudden disturbances; such as loud rapping and other sounds; the throwing of objects; the moving of furniture; the raining of stones and other small objects; strange lights; peculiar odors; and physical assaults upon humans and animals; occur.

The state of being possessed by a spirit or demon. In spirit possession, a spiritualist medium permits a spirit to enter their body for communication. In demonic possession, an entity takes control of the host, potentially displacing the host's spirit.
The paranormal or extrasensory perception of future events, often through dreams or visions; psychic awareness of things yet to happen.
A situation where a person feels unnaturally cold. Caused by a materializing spirit drawing energy from the environment or from nearby persons.

A way in which spirits sometimes communicate with the living. Ranging from light knocking sounds to heavy pounding; rapping usually emanates from the walls but often sounds as though it is coming from all around.

The rebirth of a soul into a new physical body. Reincarnation is an ancient and mystical belief belonging to a number of religions, including Wicca. It is commonly associated with the concept of spiritual evolution.

A gathering of persons to contact and receive messages from discarnate beings or spirits of the dead. Séances are traditionally held in the dark or by candlelight at a table where all persons attending are seated with hands joined to form a circle.
A being that exists without a physical body (discarnate) and is not bound by the restrictions or characteristics of the physical world. Also known as a ghost or an apparition.

As a noun, this word refers to events that have no natural explanation. It commonly refers to divine acts, but can additionally include extraordinary acts caused by negative forces. As an adjective, beyond powers or laws of nature.
The ability to transport physical objects or human beings from one place to another by supernatural means.
See Doppelganger.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a practical system for interacting with the spirit world, drawing heavily from Wiccan, Spiritualist, and traditional grimoire magic. It emphasizes personal experience, respect for spirits, and stringent protective measures. The system enables communication, evocation, summoning, and banishing of spirits, alongside comprehensive protective magic for individuals and homes. It integrates herbalism, amuletic magic, and specific ritual mechanics to achieve desired outcomes in working with the supernatural.
tools: Spirit's photograph and/or personal effects (for focus)
Image/statue of Virgin Mary or Guadalupe
Black candles (5 for Parish ritual, 2 for vampire spell)
Fennel, garlic, periwinkle, plantain (for home protection)
Horseshoe, sprig of rue (for home protection)
Five amulets in shape of dogs (Assyrian home protection)
Clover and white vinegar (to banish spirits)
Fennel seeds, dried beans, devil pods ('bat nut', 'goat head'), mistletoe, roots (angelica, devil's shoestring, orris, peony) for mojo bags
Essential oils of angelica or Saint John's wort (to anoint mojo bags)
Silver coin, silver pentagram, silver jewelry (for Ouija sessions/protection)
Abramelin Incense ingredients: myrrh, wood aloes, cinnamon oil, frankincense, storax/liquidamber resin/benzoin, lignum aloes, cedar, sandalwood
Safer conjuring incense: anise, cardamom, coriander
Spirit-departing incense: calamint, peony, spearmint, castor beans
Crucifix, garlic, poppy seeds, juniper branches, thorny branches of wild rose, thorns/stakes (for warding off vampires)
Hawthorn, maple, or aspen wood (for vampire stakes)
Forked stake surmounted by horse/ass head (against werewolves)
Wolf pelt, magical girdle, potions, magical ointment (for shapeshifting)
rituals: Spirit Evocation: Cast a clockwise circle, light a white candle, gaze into the flame, and recite an incantation invoking Hecate to materialize a specific spirit.

Spirit Banishing: After evocation, trace a banishing pentagram in the air at the East quarter (starting lower left, moving clockwise through Spirit, Fire, Air, Water, back to Earth) and plunge an athame blade through its center while reciting an incantation to Hecate. Repeat at South, West, and North quarters. Uncast the circle counter-clockwise and extinguish the candle.

Séance (Spiritualist tradition): Conduct in a darkened, well-ventilated room, free of minerals/glass. Use a round/oval table. Participants (3-12, ideally divisible by 3) relax, close eyes, visualize white spiraling light. A medium leads, potentially casting an invisible clockwise circle with an athame. Join hands (left up, right down) to form a circuit. Begin with a prayer (e.g., Psalm 23 or Pagan prayer to Lady and Lord). Call to the spirit, patiently await signs (raps, cold chill, flickering candle flame). Ask yes/no questions (one rap for yes, two for no). Conclude by giving thanks, breaking the circle, and extinguishing the candle.

Spirit Summoning (Necromantic): At the witching hour (waning moon), place a cauldron at deserted crossroads. Burn dried willow bark inscribed with the spirit's name, mixed with crushed sandalwood. Recite an incantation invoking Hecate to manifest the spirit in human form.

Spell to Enable Contact with a Spirit: On a full moon night, anoint sandalwood incense with white willow oil. Light it and concentrate on the deceased's name. Continue until incense burns out, then proceed to make contact via a chosen method.

Jeffrey Parish's Spirit Ritual: Set up an altar with an image of the Virgin Mary/Guadalupe, white roses, patchouli oil, calendula flowers, pomegranates, and personal effects of the loved one. Dress five black candles with patchouli oil and arrange them. In total darkness, light a censer with incense, anoint forehead/heart with patchouli. Light candles one by one, recalling fond memories. Meditate, then recite a prayer ('Our Blessed Lady, Cleanse my mind...'). Engage in conversation with the loved one, paying attention to signs (e.g., candle flame dancing, scent of perfume).

Exorcising a Poltergeist (17th-century formula): Recite the adjuration: 'I adjure you, ancient serpent, by the Judge of the living and the dead, by the Creator of the universe, who has power to send you to Gehenna, that you depart forthwith from this house. He orders you to do so, cursed devil, who ordered the winds and the sea and the tempests. He orders you who ordered you to go back. Hearken, therefore, Satan, and be afraid, and withdraw, subdued and prostrate.'

Psychic Vampire Powerless Spell: Create a poppet, adding a photograph of the target and personal items (hair, clothing threads). Charge the poppet by chanting the vampire's name. Place the poppet between two burning black candles on an altar and recite the incantation nine times: 'Psychic vampire set me free. No powers have you over me. By number three times number three, All harm you’ve done returns to thee!' Drive a wooden stake through the poppet's 'heart' shouting 'So mote it be!'

relevant_quotes.text: “Whether ill-behaved or benevolent, spiritual or quasi-material, bedmates or strangers, ghosts are universal; they haunt virtually every culture, Eastern and Western.”
“Millions of spiritual creatures walk the earth unseen, both when we wake, and when we sleep.”
“Poltergeists are spirits that seem intent on causing trouble.”
“By and large, it is entirely safe to be a ghost hunter or to become a witness to phenomena of this kind.”

“From earliest beginnings man has used “natural” means to catch a glance beyond the curtain that hid the future and to get into contact with the supernatural. But in modern times he also devised artificial aids to help him in his endeavors. One of the more popular ones in spiritualist circles is the Ouija board.”

Necromancy should never be thought of as some kind of parlor game. It is serious business and is not intended for causing mischief or alleviating boredom. Additionally, raising the dead should never be attempted for the purpose of carrying out evil deeds or bringing harm and misfortune to others, no matter what they might have done to you.
“If werewolves are not merely an absurd delusion, then they are evidence of some power of the human mind that we do not at present understand.”

critical_analysis.relevance: This book provides a relevant synthesis of personal experiences, historical folklore, and practical occult methods concerning the supernatural. It serves as an accessible entry point into understanding and interacting with spirits from a Witch's perspective, emphasizing safety, respect, and informed practice. Its unique value lies in combining a broad range of paranormal topics with actionable magical advice, differentiating between various spirit types and offering specific rituals for engagement and protection. The inclusion of personal narratives, an interview with a medium, and historical context makes it a valuable resource for those seeking both theoretical knowledge and practical application in esotericism.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience includes practitioners of Witchcraft, Wicca, and general occultism, as well as individuals with a keen interest in the paranormal, ghost hunting, and spiritual communication. It caters to both beginners seeking foundational understanding and more experienced individuals looking to expand their operative magical repertoire concerning spirits. The tone is encouraging but cautious, advising proper preparation and respect for the unseen, making it suitable for those ready to engage with the spirit world consciously.
